Utterance: Hi! It’s great to see you again. How have you been since our last session?
Hi, Ellie! I’ve been okay. I tried the mindfulness exercise before bed, and it helped a bit.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Physiological Observations

Utterance: That’s wonderful to hear! How did it feel to incorporate that into your routine?
It was nice. I felt more relaxed, but I still woke up a few times.
That’s a good start! It can take time to see more significant changes in sleep patterns. How about during the day? Have you noticed any changes in your mood?
I think I’ve been handling my frustration better. I didn’t yell at my neighbor this time!
That’s a big step! How did that conversation go?
I approached them calmly and said I was feeling overwhelmed by the noise. They actually apologized!
That’s fantastic! It sounds like your approach made a real difference. How did you feel afterwards?
I felt relieved. It was nice to communicate without fighting.
That’s a great example of assertive communication in action. What do you think you learned from that experience?
I learned that talking things out can be better than avoiding them. It felt good to express myself.
Absolutely! And it’s a skill you can continue to develop. Have you faced any other challenges since then?
Well, I still have moments of sadness. It’s like a wave that comes and goes.
That’s understandable, especially with your history of depression. Have you noticed any specific triggers for those waves of sadness?
Sometimes it’s just random, but other times it’s when I think about my kids and how far away they are.
Classified_Subsection: History of Present Illness (HPI): Psychosocial History

Utterance: That makes sense. It’s natural to miss loved ones. How do you cope with those feelings when they arise?
I try to distract myself with my dogs or watching a movie, but it doesn’t always work.
Distraction can be helpful, but it might be worth exploring how you can also process those feelings. Have you considered journaling about your emotions?
I’ve thought about it, but I’m not sure how to start.
Journaling can be as simple as writing down your thoughts and feelings as they come. You could start with prompts like, “Today I felt…” or “I miss my kids because…”
That sounds doable. I’ll give it a try.
Great! It may help you understand your emotions better and find patterns. Is there anything else you’d like to explore today?
I think that covers it. I just want to keep improving.
That’s a healthy mindset. Remember to be patient with yourself. Progress takes time. I’m proud of the steps you’ve taken.
Thank you, Ellie. I appreciate your support.
Of course! I’m here for you. Let’s check in on your journaling and any other developments next time. Take care until then!
Will do! See you soon, Ellie.
Goodbye!
